problem: Find the quotient when $x^6 - 3$ is divided by $x + 1.$
solution:
We can perform long division.  Alternatively, by the Remainder Theorem, the remainder upon division is $(-1)^6 - 3 = -2.$  Thus, we can write
\begin{align*}
\frac{x^6 - 3}{x + 1} &= \frac{(x^6 - 1) - 2}{x + 1} \\
&= \frac{x^6 - 1}{x + 1} - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= \frac{(x^3 - 1)(x^3 + 1)}{x + 1} - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= \frac{(x^3 - 1)(x + 1)(x^2 - x + 1)}{x + 1} - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= (x^3 - 1)(x^2 - x + 1) - \frac{2}{x + 1} \\
&= x^5 - x^4 + x^3 - x^2 + x - 1 - \frac{2}{x + 1}.
\end{align*}Thus, the quotient is $\boxed{x^5 - x^4 + x^3 - x^2 + x - 1}.$
gptanswer:
Using polynomial long division, we have:

\[
\begin{array}{c|ccccc}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{x^5} & -x^4 & +x^3 & -x^2 & +x \\ \cline{2-6}
x+1 & x^6 & & & & -3 \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{-x^6} & -x^5 & & & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{\phantom{-}x^5} & & & & \\
\cline{2-3}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & -x^5 & & & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & \phantom{-}x^5 & +x^4 & & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & \multicolumn{1}{r}{-x^5} & & & \\
\cline{3-4}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 & x^4 & & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & -x^4 & -x^3 & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & \phantom{-}x^4 & & \\
\cline{4-5}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & 0 & -x^3 & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & x^3 & +x^2 & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & -x^3 & & \\
\cline{5-6}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & 0 & x^2 & \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & & -x^2 & -x \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & & \phantom{-}x^2 & \\
\cline{6-6}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & & 0 & -x \\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{} & & & & & \phantom{-}x-3 \\
\end{array}
\]

Therefore, the quotient is $\boxed{x^5 - x^4 + x^3 - x^2 + x - (x+3)/(x+1)}.$
